title: American_Top_40_1980 February_23rd
description:
"Every week on American Top 40 we countdown the most popular songs in the USA from Lead Hill, Arkansas, to Leadville , Colorado, and at number 21 in our countdown this week here is Led Zeppelin with 'Fool In The Rain'."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is one I found originally torrented on Demonoid.

In this countdown:

Queen has their first number one hit.

The song ABC-TV used as the theme for the 1980 Winter Olympics is in the countdown.

Casey answers a letter that reads, "Dear Casey, I'd like to know how many song titles about writing letters have hit number one. The answer would be particularly interesting to people in my line of work. Signed: The Post-Master General of the United States."

There is a woman in the countdown whose male fans are so intense that to prove their adoration, one man swam a mile across the Mississippi and another destroyed his own car with a sledgehammer. Casey gives the details.

A listener wants to know if any songs about sports teams or athletes have ever charted. Casey says there was one about a home-run champ, and another about a champion boxer.

Casey tells how "Hey Jude" (the biggest hit The Beatles ever had) came to be written.
